article.title: Quantum Zeno and anti-Zeno effects in quantum dissipative systems

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the effective decay rate (Γ(τ)) of a pure dephasing qubit-boson model for different initial states and system-bath coupling strengths. Which of the following statements is **incorrect** based on the figure?
choices: For the initial state |ψ(0)〉 = (|e〉 + |g〉)/√2, the effective decay rate exhibits a peak structure, indicating a crossover between the quantum Zeno effect (QZE) and quantum anti-Zeno effect (QAZE) regimes.
For the initial state |ψ(0)〉 = |e〉, neither the QZE nor the QAZE occurs as the effective decay rate remains zero.
Stronger system-bath coupling (larger λ) leads to a more pronounced peak in the effective decay rate, suggesting a faster transition between QZE and QAZE regimes.
The numerical results obtained using the HEOM method perfectly match the exact analytical solutions, validating the accuracy of the numerical technique.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 illustrates the effective decay rate (Γ(τ)) of a biased qubit-spin model for different system-bath coupling strengths and compares the numerical HEOM method with a perturbative approach. What can be concluded from the figure?
choices: The perturbative approach accurately predicts the effective decay rate for both weak and strong system-bath coupling strengths.
The biased qubit-spin model exhibits multiple peaks in the effective decay rate, suggesting multiple Zeno-anti-Zeno transition phenomena.
The presence of multiple peaks is more prominent in weaker system-bath coupling strengths.
The logarithm of the effective decay rate (ln[Γ(τ)]) at τ=0 is larger for the Markovian bath compared to the non-Markovian bath.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 shows the effective decay rate (Γ(τ)) of a pure dephasing qutrit-boson model for an initial state |ψ(0)〉 = |s, J〉. What does the figure indicate about the Zeno-anti-Zeno transition in this model?
choices: Similar to the biased qubit-boson model, the qutrit-boson model exhibits multiple Zeno-anti-Zeno transitions, indicated by multiple peaks in the effective decay rate.
The qutrit-boson model exhibits a single peak in the effective decay rate, implying a single Zeno-anti-Zeno transition.
The value of the effective decay rate at τ=0 is larger for the non-Markovian bath compared to the Markovian bath.
The occurrence of multiple Zeno-anti-Zeno crossover phenomena is independent of the characteristics of the bath density spectral function.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 displays the effective decay rate (Γ(τ)) of a biased qutrit-spin model for different spectral widths (λ) and tunneling parameters (ε/Δ). What does the figure suggest about the impact of these parameters on the Zeno-anti-Zeno transition?
choices: A wider spectral width (larger λ) corresponds to a faster transition between QZE and QAZE regimes.
A smaller tunneling parameter (smaller ε/Δ) leads to a more pronounced peak in the effective decay rate.
The non-Markovianity of the bath has no significant impact on the Zeno-anti-Zeno transition.
Multiple Zeno-anti-Zeno transitions are observed only for specific combinations of spectral width and tunneling parameter.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 illustrates the effective decay rate (Γ(τ)) of the biased qubit-boson and qutrit-boson models at different temperatures. What can be inferred from the figure regarding the influence of bath temperature on the QZE?
choices: The high bath temperature may facilitate the observation of QZE in quantum dissipative systems.
The multiple Zeno-anti-Zeno crossover phenomena disappear at finite temperatures.
The value of the quantum Zeno time at high bath temperature is longer than that of the low temperature case.
The high bath temperature may hinder the realization of QZE in quantum dissipative systems due to reduced non-Markovianity.
